settings.title: Guide to Maintaining & Caring for Planters
settings.text: Wooden planters add a touch of natural elegance to your garden, patio, or balcony. However, to keep them looking their best and to extend their lifespan, it’s essential to follow proper care and maintenance practices. In this guide, we'll show you how to clean, protect, and maintain your wooden planter, ensuring it remains as stunning as the day you brought it home.

settings.text:
1. Regular Cleaning

Cleaning your wooden planter is key to preventing the buildup of dirt, mildew, and algae, which can cause damage over time. Here’s how to clean it properly:

  • Step 1: Remove any soil and plants from the planter.
  • Step 2: Use a soft brush to sweep off loose dirt and debris.
  • Step 3: Mix warm water with a mild detergent. Avoid using harsh chemicals, as they can strip the wood of its protective oils.
  • Step 4: Use a sponge or soft cloth to gently scrub the surface. For stubborn areas, a soft-bristled brush can help.
  • Step 5: Rinse the planter with clean water and allow it to air dry completely in a shaded area before replanting.
3. Applying UV Protection

Exposure to sunlight can cause wood to fade and dry out. To protect your wooden planter from harmful UV rays, use a UV-resistant wood treatment:

  • Choose the right treatment: Look for a wood preserver that includes UV inhibitors. These treatments are designed to penetrate the wood and create a protective barrier. We highly recommend Osmo Oil, having tried and tested this ourselves.
  • Seasonal Consideration: Apply treatments in dry weather to allow proper absorption and drying.

Reapply every 6-12 months minimum to maintain the colour of your panels, and prevent against any weather-related damage.

5. Winter Care Tips

Cold weather and frost can be harsh on wooden planters. Here’s how to prepare your planters for winter:

  • Move planters indoors: If possible, move smaller planters to a sheltered area, such as a shed or garage, during winter months.
  • Use protective covers: If moving indoors isn’t an option, cover your wooden planter with a breathable fabric to protect it from frost and snow.
  • Raise it off the ground: Elevate the planter to prevent prolonged exposure to wet surfaces, which can accelerate rot.
6. Inspect for Damage

Regular inspections are important to spot signs of wear and tear before they become serious problems. Look out for:

  • Cracks or splits in the wood: These may need sealing or sanding down.
  • Loose joints or fasteners: Tighten any screws or fixings to keep the planter stable.
  • Signs of mold or rot: Treat affected areas immediately with a wood preservative or fungicide.

settings.overlay_text: By following these steps, you can extend the life of your wooden planter and keep it looking beautiful year after year. With regular cleaning, UV treatment, and protection from water and weather, your wooden planter will remain a charming feature in your garden for years to come.
